For those who just want to contribute €5 to help us out, an option to do that too.  Every little bit helps.

 

Notes:
- All prices are exclusive of shipping costs.  Shipping for the lyrics or for the tour pass are €10 per item (combined shipping isn't possible if you order both, since they are being shipped from two separate locations), and shipping for the T-shirt or T-shirt/tour pass combo is €15. 
- The T-shirts will be manufactured to order based on the quantity (maximum 100 sold) and sizes of each order, and shall not be available after this campaign.
- The tour pass will gain you free entry into any Crippled Black Phoenix show (other than festival appearances, shows which CBP are not headlining, fundraising/charity appearances or unique events. The tour pass may already be used for the forthcoming March/April 2019 dates, and will be valid for CBP live shows through December 31st, 2020.  If using the tour pass, please let us know by sending us an e-mail or Facebook message at least three (3) days prior to such event, to prevent issues with maximum venue capacity.  The tour pass shall not entitle you to backstage access or special entry.  
 

Spread the word!
If you can't assist or aren't interested in any of the perks here, we ask that you still help us out and share the word of this campaign with your friends.  There are share tools provided via Indiegogo to make this even easier.  
Come see us live!
Here are the dates, so come see us on tour (Crippled Black Phoenix/Soft Kill/Fotocrime)19.03 - Scunthorpe, UK @ Cafe Indie (no Soft Kill)20.03 - Manchester, UK @ Rebellion (no Soft Kill)21.03 - London, UK @ Underworld22.03 - Brighton, UK @ Patterns23.03 - Osnabrück, DE @ Bastard Club24.03 - Hamburg, DE @ Knust25.03 - Aarhus, DK @ Voxhall26.03 - Stockholm, SE @ Kraken27.03 - Copenhagen, DK @ Vega28.03 - Berlin, DE @ BiNuu29.03 - Dresden, DE @ Scheune30.03 - Prague, CZ @ Underdogs01.04 - Aschaffenburg, DE @ Colos-saal02.04 - Martigny, CH @ Caves du Manoir03.04 - Vaureal, FR @ Le Forum04.04 - Strasbourg, FR @ La Laiterie05.04 - Nimes, FR @ La Paloma06.04 - Luzern, CH @ Schüür07.04 - Villingen Schwenningen, DE @ Klosterhof08.04 - Vienna, AT @ Arena09.04 - Munich, DE @ Feierwerk10.04 - Cologne, DE @ Luxor11.04 - Tilburg, NL @ Roadburn Festival (CBP and Fotocrime)

story:
Carol Abbe Smith - Festival Chair

I have been producing and hosting Jazz events and workshops in the Pioneer Valley of Western Massachusetts for over 10 years. Aside from producing, I am a jazz musician and have been fortunate to work with many of the best regional and national artists. I am also fortunate that we have a lineup of incredible musicians ready to perform at this premier Jazz Festival. I have a great team working with me to make this festival a success as well as a starter grant from Easthampton City Arts+. Team members Ruth Griggs, Marcia Morrison, Theora Gilliam, Kathy Service, Fred Andresen, George Kaye, and Wayne Roberts hope that by making our campaign goal, we will be able to make this festival totally free to the public while paying our participating musicians what they are worth.

The Campaign Goal

In order to the make this a free festival, we have to raise a minimum of $10,000. We have received a grant from Easthampton City Arts+ for $2,500. The vast majority of the money raised will be for paying the professional musicians ($9000), with the rest going to pay for space rental, programs and advertising.

We hope to have some generous local sponsors help us reach our goal. If we fail to raise enough total money, we will keep the daytime events free and the evening concert at a minimum ticket price.

Any amount raised will help us reach our goal.  Think of what you would be willing to pay for just one band concert.  At the Easthampton Jazz Festival, you will get a full day of music presented by at least 10 bands!

The Venues

Eastworks (116 Pleasant St) is a 500,000-square-foot converted mill building in the heart of Easthampton housing celebrated artists, creative entrepreneurs, local and national businesses, restaurants and residents.  The festival will be on the first floor in the 121 Club and in the spacious hallways.

Easthampton High School Auditorium (70 Williston Ave) is in the all new High School and is a state-of-art performance space.

The Music

Eastworks - 12 Noon to 5:30 PM   

Here's the current lineup at the 121 Club (subject to change):

Ginja Low Main - Rob Fontana piano, John Phillips guitar, Joey Sicard bass, Kade Parkin drums

Kimaya Diggs and Friends - Franz Roberts piano, Andrew Jones bass, Sam Jones drums

Ellington Trio - Miro Sprague piano, Wayne Roberts bass and Michael Zsoldos saxophone

Lizzie Meier/Stephen Kerr Duo

Darryl Kniffen Sextet - Franz Robert piano, Jason Schwartz bass, Matthew Stickler alto saxophone, Dylan Canterbury trumpet, Shawn McCarthy guitar

In the common areas of Eastworks throughout the afternoon:   Holyoke Community College Jazz Band, South Hadley High School Big Band, and Northampton Community Music School Jazz Band.

Easthampton High School  6pm -10pm  Hosted by Tom Reney of NEPR's Jazz A La Mode

Easthampton High School Band will start us off, then...

7 PM - Porgy and Bess, George Kayes' adaptation of the Miles/Evans arrangement, featuring Samirah Evans vocals, Miro Sprague piano, George Kaye bass, Claire Arenius drums, Michael Zsoldos saxophone, and Tim Atherton trombone.

8:15 PM - The Andy Jaffe Octet featuring original music from the CD "Arc" by Andy Jaffe composer/arranger, with Andy Jaffe piano, Wallace Roney trumpet, Jimmy Greene tenor saxophone, Kris Allen reeds, John Clark french horn, Bruce Williamson reeds, Marty Jaffe bass, and Jonathon Barber drums.

We hope that, with your support, we can make this the must-attend jazz event of the year!

Check out the festival website for photos and music from participants at www.easthamptonjazzfestival.squarespace.com or on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/EasthamptonJazzfestival/.

story:
My last album, The Prince’s Tale, told the heartbreaking story from the chapter of the same name at the end of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, and I released it in 2011. That’s where this story begins. 

Over the last seven years, my life has changed a lot. I went from a touring musician to a YouTube content creator and Etsy shop owner making tons of projects out of my home studio, and now I’m a full-time mom working overtime to continue creating the various kinds of art that I’m passionate about. I may not have narrowly escaped utter peril to save the wizarding world in these seven years, but since my last album, songwriting has become something that I’ve struggled to do. Whenever I sat down to write, I found myself getting stuck and losing confidence. 

When I finally did finish a song, it felt so incredibly good and those songs have truly resonated with people. I’ve been spending increasingly more time on each song that I write, waiting until I'm truly happy with every aspect of each one before releasing it - I think that's one of the reasons why I'm so proud of them. 

As I continued to perform at occasional concerts and nerd conventions, one question at my merch table became more and more common: “Can I buy the album with ‘Home’ on it?” - Sadly, I've had to turn down every person who has asked. 

I am overjoyed to announce that I finally have a positive answer to that question. I've spent an entire Hogwarts education writing ten songs that I am completely in love with, and I'm finally ready to release them on an album. 

 

It’s called With You, Whatever Happens. 

With your help, I am setting out to release an album full of songs that will make you feel accepted for who you are and a little less alone. They are uplifting, motivating, and hopeful - and they include plenty of nerdy nostalgia for anyone who loves the Harry Potter series and John Green’s books. I had also set out to focus on some of the incredible women in the Harry Potter series, so on this album, you will hear songs about Luna Lovegood, Hermione Granger, Ginny Weasley, and for the first time since 2009 - Myrtle Elizabeth Warren. 

With my initial goal of $2500, I planned to mix the album myself and have it professionally mastered. It will be released digitally in online music stores and I’ll also be able to make a small run of physical CDs. This goal also covers perk fulfillment costs and my time working on the album. Once we reached that goal (YAY!), I set a stretch goal of $6500 that would allow me to work with a professional producer to mix the entire album, giving it a sound that I couldn’t have accomplished on my own. Thanks to all of you, we passed that goal too! 

Being part of such an accepting and wonderful community of Harry Potter fans has changed my life for the better. I would love to give back to this fandom by creating my best wizard rock album yet, and thanks to your support, I am so excited to be able to make that happen. 

 

Reserve your copy now!

Even though the campaign has ended, I've extended the ability to preorder the album while I'm recording it. You can still place orders for a digital copy as well as an autographed physical copy, which is usually only available in person at my concerts. 

Follow this page to receive updates on the album as it comes together! I'll be writing newsletters every few weeks until "With You, Whatever Happens" is released to keep you up-to-date on the timeline and new information about the album itself. 

 

Hear from others

  • “Lauren's music often articulates a sense of community for me. I sometimes struggle with explaining how my love for Harry Potter is not necessarily dependent on the books/movies/etc but something else. In her songs she explains that 'something else' better than I ever could.” -@RavenclawHallow
  • "I'm tempted to say 'sunshine in music form', but in all seriousness, Lauren's music is the epitome of earnestness and sincerity. Her music helps us all feel a little less alone.” -@lianegraham
  • "Everything Lauren has released, from Myrtles and Wizard Rock music to muggle music and even covers, has been so important to me in some of the most formative parts of my life. They’ve helped me understand not only myself but the world and the way I interact with it. Listening to her music makes me laugh, it makes me cry, it brings me back to some of my favorite memories with my friends, in libraries and convention centers and basements. It’s like coming home.” -@lunatunarox
  • “It's what reminds me to turn on the light when things get dark” -@queerwitches
  • “Lauren's music is like sitting down with a life long friend after a long period of separation. There are shared laughs and so many stories to exchange.” -@wrenward
  • "Often joyful, always sincere and always heartfelt. If I feel sad, I put on some of her songs to cheer me up and it always works.” -@evelynblake712
  • "Her music is inspiring and catchy and brings me home. She sings about everything good in our fandom and is a staple in our community. I can't imagine wizard rock without Lauren Fairweather.” -@BandGeekEB
  • “Lauren's music means so much to me. Whenever I am having a bad day, I need some extra light in my life, just need to escape for a while, or just need to think about happy times for a bit it is always the first place I go to. Her music is a huge part of my self-care routine and always makes me feel better. There are so many amazing messages that I have needed to hear at different points in my life.” -@Bam721_

Has my music affected you in a positive way? Post about it on social media along with a link to this campaign. 

 

Thank you so much for your time and support. 

I'm so excited to be able to make this seven-year project a reality and your help has made it possible. I can't wait to share this album with you - I just know that you're going to love it.

story:
About Me

I was born and raised in the musically rich city of Hamilton Ontario and grew up listening to artists like Teenage Head, Edgar Breau and Fred Purser and The Washingtons. I was inspired by the guitar playing of Brian Griffith and the writing and producing of Daniel Lanois. 

I spent most of the early 90's playing in Hess Village with Creepin' Chester while I studied jazz at Mohawk College. I continued to play throughout the years, but didn't really start songwriting again until I took part in Lori Yates' Creative Genius Songwriting Workshop a few years ago. I write about personal experiences, love and loss and my respect and admiration for nature and the human spirit. I'm happiest when I'm creating.

The current project I am working on, and asking you to support is a solo record in the Folk/Singer-songwriter vein. Two of the songs have competed in The CBC Searchlight Contest. The most recent one, "That's What I Would Do" advanced to the third round as a Hamilton Regional Finalist. Have a listen: https://www.reverbnation.com/jamieshea/song/231...

 

  • I love to write songs that have meaning.
  • I want to share them with as many people as I can.
  • I'm recording my first album and need your financial support.

 

What I Need & What You Get

I've managed to save some money from gigs over the past year, and have two of the ten songs recorded in sessions from previous years. I'm looking to raise $5000 to pay for the remaining studio sessions, production and design.

  • I'll take whatever you can afford to give me
  • Perks include the record itself, private performances and access to my blog that takes you behind the scenes for every one of my recording sessions 
  • I fully expect to reach or surpass my flexible funding goal, but if I don't, I will still make the best record I can.

 

The Impact your contribution will make

  • Your financial support will buy me the time I need to make sure the project is done properly. I won't have to rush through and make compromises.
  • You'll be supporting the arts in a time when cuts are being made in our name.
  • You will be making a powerful statement. Do something positive with your money.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're strapped for cash, you can still make a difference by spreading the word to music lovers like yourself.

  • Word of mouth goes a long way. "Hey, Jamie Shea's making a record!" is a great way to start a conversation with your music-loving friends.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story: I am writing this to ask for your financial help in producing the 2017 Providence Folk Festival. This will be the fourth year of the festival and it is always the hard to raise funding. The PVD Folk Fest won the Motif Magazine Award for BEST FESTIVAL in RI for 2016! We have do have some funding but require much more to make the event a success. There are a LOT of hidden costs, as well as the obvious ones in producing a festival. We must cover advertising, staging, tents, sound, lights, sanitation, licenses, talent fees and many other production costs. Hear In Rhode Island is a non-profit organization and is experienced with festival and event production. HIRI started and ran the Hear In Rhode Island Festival from 1994-2001. That festival presented over 100 acts on four stages during the two day event. Hear In RI also produced a stage at the Newport Folk Festival for nine years. For the past six years HIRI has been producing the Downtown Sundown Series at Roger Williams National Memorial in downtown Providence. This successful series involves 5-6 shows spaced out over the summer months. Roger Williams National Memorial is a beautiful park and is the actual location of the original Providence settlement back in 1636.  In addition to all the previously mentioned events, HIRI has produced many other shows, CDs, workshops and more. HIRI is a certified non-profit organization operating under the 501(c)(3) code. All donations are tax deductible. We have set up different levels of sponsorship that make it easy for you to help. There are also perks involved such as t-shirts, pins, signed posters and more. Please check for specific levels for the specific perks. The BIGGEST perk of all will be the SATISFACTION in knowing that you helped something great happen. We hope that you can assist us and more than anything we hope that you will come to the festival on Sunday, August 27th. Thank you!

story:
Who we are

My name is Eyal Vilner and I’m a jazz musician and composer based in NYC. I play saxophone, clarinet and flute. For the past 10 years I’ve been leading my 18-piece big band, writing new arrangements of jazz classics, composing original music and conducting the band. I see the big band as another one of my instruments through which I try to express myself.

I was born in Tel Aviv, Israel and moved to New York when I was 21 to complete my studies at the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. I started the big band the following year,  and since then, we’ve been fortunate to perform regularly at many NYC major jazz clubs like Jazz at Lincoln Center - Dizzy’s Club, Smalls, Birdland, Swing 46 and The Django. The band tours frequently in Israel and has performed at venues including the Tel Aviv Museum, the Jerusalem Theater and the Red Sea Jazz Festival. Our last three albums; Introducing the Eyal Vilner Big Band, Almost Sunrise and Hanukkah made it to the top of the jazz radio charts in the US and Canada and received rave reviews.

 

What’s special about this album?

In the past few years, we’ve started playing more and more for swing dancers. This has really influenced the way I play and write music. I fell in love with the dance and have become really passionate about the connection between musicians and dancers in the swing world. In this album we strive to create something new in this genre and tell our story through these aesthetics. Together with professional dancer and international instructor Gaby Cook and a group of amazing dancers we started a weekly jam in NYC where dancers and musicians get together to improvise and learn about each other’s language and art form, inviting artists from different backgrounds to collaborate and create something beautiful together. This exchange between dance and music, movement and sound, feels so refreshing and new - yet so natural and familiar. It feels like we’re bringing it back to where jazz and swing dancing grew up and developed together, influenced and inspired by one another. It feels like we’re bringing it back home.

 

Funding

Recording an album is not cheap, let alone an 18-piece big band album! Our goal for the campaign is $15,000, which is the minimum we need in order to make it happen. The money raised in this campaign will help pay for the musicians, 2 days at the recording studio, mixing, mastering, artwork and design, and printing the new album.

 

Tax Deductible

All contributions are fully tax-deductible through our long-term partnership with the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, excluding the cost of goods and services received.


Who’s in the band?

The Eyal Vilner Big Band is an 18-piece jazz orchestra that includes some of the finest musicians in New York City. Some of them have joined the band within the past few years, and some I grew up with, and we’ve been playing jazz together since we were teenagers in Tel Aviv! Our two featured vocalists are the amazing Brianna Thomas and Brandon Bain! I absolutely love their singing and storytelling and they bring such great energy and vibes to the band.

 

The musicians:

Brianna Thomas & Brandon Bain - vocals

 

Bryan Davis - lead trumpet

James Zollar - trumpet and flugelhorn

Brandon Lee - trumpet and flugelhorn

Michael Sailors - trumpet and flugelhorn

 

Robert Edwards - trombone

Mariel Bildsten - trombone

Ron Wilkins - bass trombone

 

Bill Todd - alto sax, clarinet and flute

Jordan Pettay - alto sax, clarinet and flute

Evan Arntzen - tenor sax, clarinet

Michael Hashim - tenor sax

Eden Bareket - baritone sax

 

Jordan Piper - piano

Ian Hutchison - bass

Eran Fink - drums

 

Yours truly, Eyal Vilner - alto sax, clarinet and flute, compositions, arrangements and conducting

 

 

Thank you so much for your support! You can also help us by posting and sharing this project.

We look forward to sharing this special part of our journey with you!

As they say: Take care of the music and it will take care of you!

Eyal

 

 

Credits:

Video editing by: Brandon Bain

Cover picture by: Nina Galicheva, from the Intrepid: Battle of the Big Bands by Prohibition Productions

Videos by: Phil Douglas, Brandon Bain, Eldon Phillips, Mika Orr, Roy Herzlich, Grayson Dantzic, Nikki Birch  

Special thanks to Swing 46 for letting us shoot the interview at the club!
story_txt:
Who we are
My name is Eyal Vilner and I’m a jazz musician and composer based in NYC. I play saxophone, clarinet and flute. For the past 10 years I’ve been leading my 18-piece big band, writing new arrangements of jazz classics, composing original music and conducting the band. I see the big band as another one of my instruments through which I try to express myself.
I was born in Tel Aviv, Israel and moved to New York when I was 21 to complete my studies at the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. I started the big band the following year,  and since then, we’ve been fortunate to perform regularly at many NYC major jazz clubs like Jazz at Lincoln Center - Dizzy’s Club, Smalls, Birdland, Swing 46 and The Django. The band tours frequently in Israel and has performed at venues including the Tel Aviv Museum, the Jerusalem Theater and the Red Sea Jazz Festival. Our last three albums; Introducing the Eyal Vilner Big Band, Almost Sunrise and Hanukkah made it to the top of the jazz radio charts in the US and Canada and received rave reviews. What’s special about this album?
In the past few years, we’ve started playing more and more for swing dancers. This has really influenced the way I play and write music. I fell in love with the dance and have become really passionate about the connection between musicians and dancers in the swing world. In this album we strive to create something new in this genre and tell our story through these aesthetics. Together with professional dancer and international instructor Gaby Cook and a group of amazing dancers we started a weekly jam in NYC where dancers and musicians get together to improvise and learn about each other’s language and art form, inviting artists from different backgrounds to collaborate and create something beautiful together. This exchange between dance and music, movement and sound, feels so refreshing and new - yet so natural and familiar. It feels like we’re bringing it back to where jazz and swing dancing grew up and developed together, influenced and inspired by one another. It feels like we’re bringing it back home.
 
Funding
Recording an album is not cheap, let alone an 18-piece big band album! Our goal for the campaign is $15,000, which is the minimum we need in order to make it happen. The money raised in this campaign will help pay for the musicians, 2 days at the recording studio, mixing, mastering, artwork and design, and printing the new album.

All contributions are fully tax-deductible through our long-term partnership with the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, excluding the cost of goods and services received.

Some of them have joined the band within the past few years, and some I grew up with, and we’ve been playing jazz together since we were teenagers in Tel Aviv! Our two featured vocalists are the amazing Brianna Thomas and Brandon Bain! I absolutely love their singing and storytelling and they bring such great energy and vibes to the band. The musicians:
Brianna Thomas & Brandon Bain - vocals
 
Bryan Davis - lead trumpet
James Zollar - trumpet and flugelhorn
Brandon Lee - trumpet and flugelhorn
Michael Sailors - trumpet and flugelhorn Robert Edwards - trombone
Mariel Bildsten - trombone
Ron Wilkins - bass trombone Bill Todd - alto sax, clarinet and flute
Jordan Pettay - alto sax, clarinet and flute
Evan Arntzen - tenor sax, clarinet
Michael Hashim - tenor sax
Eden Bareket - baritone sax Jordan Piper - piano
Ian Hutchison - bass
Eran Fink - drums Yours truly, Eyal Vilner - alto sax, clarinet and flute, compositions, arrangements and conducting
 
 
Thank you so much for your support! You can also help us by posting and sharing this project.
We look forward to sharing this special part of our journey with you!
As they say: Take care of the music and it will take care of you!
Eyal

story:
Hi, My name is Greg. I'm a singer-songwriter from Athens,Ga, and I am looking to pursue the making of my first record.

The past few years of my life have very much been a journey of self discovery and perseverance. I've gone through some hard times and some good times, but throughout all of it, I have had music at the helm of this exodus of who I thought I was to who I am becoming. Music is a very powerful thing to me. I think music can be a light in the darkest cave and a friend when it feels like you have no one.  Ever since I started music, I wanted to help people feel less alone and more understood.

So, I would like to announce, and put out into the universe, my first project. It is called "Hey, Greg" and it is an introduction to who I am and who I am becoming. My hopes for these six songs are that they can be something people can identify with and help them feel less alone and more understood.

But I can't do it alone! I need your help! Here's what it is gonna take. $3200. This money will go to producing and engineering this project. I have a good friend and musical genius who is going to help make these songs come alive. It will also go to studio time and session musicians. This money will be used for getting the job done with the best sounding outcome because with  the best production comes better possibilities of these songs helping people.

So if you are willing to give me your support and donate to this project, I will be eternally grateful to you. This potentially could kickstart my career and you will have had a part in that. But in the mean time, with your donation, I have goodies for you. Depending on which perk you choose, I've got stickers, CDs, posters, Tshirts, and more as a way to say thank you.

So yeah! Let's make this happen! I believe in this so much and hopefully you can too. Be sure to share this campaign and get the word out. The more money we raise the better the outcome. So let's do it!

story:
Composers Concordance
8th Annual CompCord Festival - 'Animals'

https://composersconcordance.wixsite.com/2018-19-season/festival-animals

Concert 1 - 'Macro & Micro'
May 5th @ 7pm
Michiko Stage 1 - 149 W 46th St, NYC 10036

A collaboration with the 'Entertaining Science' series, this concert will be a study in music of the large and extremely small fauna. First, a lecture on insect and human behavior and biology by entomologist and explorer Dr. Mark Moffett, including his latest book, The Human Swarm, where he applies lessons from animal societies to our species. Then compositions examining extraordinary life forms on our planet!

Composers: Carlos José Castro Mora, Dan Cooper, Jane Getter, Ginka Mizuki, Gene Pritsker, David Rozenblatt, Matija Strnisa, Dave Soldier, Richard Sussman, and Zihan Yu.

Performers: CompCord Ensemble: Michiyo Suzuki - clarinet; Gene Pritsker - electric guitar; Richard Sussman, Jai Jeffryes - piano; Laurence Goldman - bass; and David Rozenblatt - percussion.

Concert 2: 'Animal Gallery'
May 10th @ 8pm
Estonian House - 234 E 34th St, NYC 10016

An all-star lineup takes inspiration from photographs, artworks, and short films of various animals. Composers and performers will present compositions that transform those influences into sound, as images of the works that prompted their creativity are shown onscreen during the performance.

Composers: Tommy Campbell, Dan Cooper, Robert Fokkens, Mark Kostabi, Lukas Ligeti, Gene Pritsker, Faye-Ellen Silverman, David Taylor, Christopher Vassiliades, Randall Woolf.

Performers: Kathleen Supové, Mark Kostabi, Christopher Vassiliades - piano; Lara St. John, Darragh Morgan - violin; David Taylor - bass trombone; and Tommy Campbell - drums.

Concert 3: 10th Annual Comp-Play-Comp Marathon - 'Animal Theme'
May 12th @ 6pm
DROM NYC - 85 Avenue A, NYC 10009

For the 10th consecutive year, we invite dozens of composer-performers to answer a question - 'What kind of music do you compose if you know you're to be one of the performers?' This time around, we add a theme into the fray, as composers are asked to write 4-minute works on the theme of 'Animals.' The 3-hour marathon will showcase amazing composer-performers in a cavalcade of short pieces. (As an added bonus this year, since the concert date's also Mother's Day, the composers have been instructed that music about animals and their mothers will receive extra points!)

Composer-Performers: Bruce Arnold, Angela Babin, Veracity Butcher, Greg Baker, John Clark, Charles Coleman, Dan Cooper, Shanan Estreicher, Peter Fabrizio, Valerie Geffner, Monroe Golden, Peter Jarvis, Debra Kaye, Alon Nechushtan, Milica Paranosic, Todd Perlmutter, Gene Pritsker, David Saperstein, Judi Silvano, William Schimmel, Dave Soldier, Roger Tréfousse, Ann Warren, Sammy Weissberg, Stefan Zeniuk, others TBA.

Concert 4: 'Remix of the Animals'
May 16th @ 9pm
Bar Thalia - Symphony Space - 2537 Broadway, NYC 10025

Camille Saint-Saëns' 'Carnival of the Animals' is the impetus for this program, for which we asked composers either to provide electronic remixes, or to write original electronic compositions. We wanted to create an informal context in which the audience can enjoy food, drinks, and electronic music premieres simultaneously, and the friendly, café atmosphere of Symphony Space's Bar Thalia provides the perfect setting!

Composer-Performers: Lynn Bechtold, Seth Boustead, Svjetlana Bukvich, Dan Cooper, Velizar Iordanov, Patti Kilroy, Mark Kostabi, Jeremy Mayall, Daniel Palkowski, Milica Paranosic, Gene Pritsker, Roger Tréfousse, Zach Seely.

Concert 5:  'Mostly Mutts' Art' with a live 'Best in Show'
May 19th @ 5pm
St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery, 131 E 10th St, NYC 10003

This concert's one for the dogs! All the music will have been inspired in some way by our canine companions. We invite audience members to bring along their dogs to participate in a Best In Show. Yes, the dogs will amble around St. Marks Church, and then a judge will pick the cutest dog to grace the event! The winner will receive Human / Canine Fashion Accessories by designer Milica Paranosic. Rose the Singing Dog might just sing along to some of the music performed. (-We don't know yet whether Rose will actually perform or will perhaps be too shy, so come by and see for yourself!)

Composers: Paul Carlon, Dan Cooper, Mark Egan, Gene Pritsker, Sebastian Pritsker, Joseph Pehrson, Eugene McBride, Monroe Golden, Roger Tréfousse, Jay Rodriguez.

Performers: Jay Rodriguez, Paul Carlon - soprano sax; Gerson Galante - alto sax; Denise Stillwell - violin; Eugene McBride, Roger Tréfousse, Jai Jeffryes - piano; Sebastian Pritsker, Rose the Singing Dog - vocals.

______________________________________________________________________________________

We hope that you'll consider a tax-deductible donation to Composers Concordance today, so that the 8th Annual CompCord Festival - 'Animals' will be a smashing success, and so that we can continue bringing such varied and exciting programming to you in future seasons! Thanks as always! -CC Team

______________________________________________________________________________________

story:
My Story

My name is Michelle Daly and I am singer and songwriter from Dublin, Ireland. 

I am classically trained singer and began performing as a child at festival competitions throughout Ireland.  As a teenager I relocated to the UK to study music and voice. I have always been heavily influenced by jazz and soul music and from a young age began writing my own songs. While in London,  working as a voice teacher and opera singer, I self-funded and released my debut EP Melodramas with co-writer Michael Parle in 2014, which we performed together on the London circuit. 

Since relocating to Berlin a few years ago I began working on new material with my collaborator composer Michael Edwards and have been performing at the regular smoky Berlin joints and top Jazz venues.  

 

My new music and album project

My influences span from the jazz and soul vocalists of the early 20th century to neo-soul/trip hop vocalists of the 90's/early 00's. These are reflected in my music and vocal style which can range from soulful to operatic.  My new material has been described as more soulful while maintaining a jazz aesthetic and utilising classic pop structures. The instrumentation will be mainly acoustic and I will be exploring richer textures on this album.

 

How you can help

Your contributions will enable me to bring my project to life. It will give me the opportunity to record, mix and master the album. Like all independent artists, I don’t have the financial support of a record label, so  rely heavily on the generosity of my supporters.

Your with your help I can:

  • Hire a top Berlin studio where I can record the album.
  • Pay my creative team: producer, session musicians and artist for the album artwork.
  • Pay for the digital distribution and CD production of the album. 

 

How to donate and what you will get in return

You can donate to the campaign by selecting one of the many perks available.

Donate without Perk - If you would like to donate an amount this is not available in the list of Perks simply click 'Back it' and input the amount you want to give. I will then make sure that you receive a perk of your choice that matches the amount that you have given (subject to availability)

Perks

  • With as a little as a  €12 donation you will be the first to hear the album as a digital download
  • Higher donations will also get you the album on CD
  • A specially designed booklet including all the lyrics on the album
  • There will also be other fun perks such as special video messages and mentions in the album notes. Take a look at what is on offer! 
  • If you would prefer to donate without receiving a perk that is also possible. Just click 'Back It' and follow the steps. 

 

Timeline 

 

If you can't give financially no problem

Share the Campaign

I would be so grateful for your help with sharing my campaign as much as possible with your networks, social media or just good old fashioned word of mouth. Please do not underestimate how helpful this will be for the success of the campaign. Help me go viral! 

  • On social media; twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Instagram, Snap chat etc
  • Emailing the link to your friends and family 
  • Or by good old fashioned word of mouth

I am so grateful for all the support I have received so far and hope that you can continue with me on this journey. 

Love 

Michelle 

www.michelledalymusic.com

Video by Shank Fotographie 

http://schankfotografie.com/

story:
My plan is to deliver to you a very high-end professional studio album with a full band.  I’ve searched the Bay Area looking for the highest quality and most professional studio and engineer. And I’m excited to say that I’ll be working with the fabulous Adam Muñoz at the legendary Fantasy Studios in Berkeley, CA.

Fantasy Studios is known around the world and has recorded some really important musicians: Santana, Tony Bennett, Aerosmith, En Vogue, Journey! And Adam Muñoz has recorded some of my favorite singers including Chris Isaak, Bonnie Raitt, Mike Patton, and Paula Cole.

I can’t wait for you to hear these songs. They’re the tightest and most lyrically honest of my work to date. I’ve started recording and the video above has some sneak peeks of me in the studio.

With your support, I can also bring in other pro musicians to help flesh out these songs and really raise them up. These songs are so close to being fully realized – with your help we can give them a life of their own.

Here's a Break-Down of Estimated Recording Costs for 9 Songs

Tracking Drums and Bass (20 hours) = $2200

Electric Guitar Overdubs (16 hours) = $1760

Acoustic Instrument Overdubs: Acoustic Guitar, Piano, Mandolin (16 hours) = $1760

Lead Vocal Overdubs (24 hours) = $2640

Back Up Vocal Overdubs (16 hours) = $1760

Mixing (40 hours) = $4400

Mastering = $600

Total: $15,120

“So why should you fund it?”  Well, you’ll get a well-crafted, lyrically honest Rock Americana record and the good will knowing that you helped make it with me, an independent artist. Plus, I have some perks to help sweeten the deal. That includes a private house concert. Or making Pasta All’amatriciana for you.

If you’re saying, “How do I know Dylan is going to actually finish the album?” Well, I have a great track record of releasing 3 albums (See Links Below). Just ask my friends. I’m driven and I don’t give up. Seriously, I don’t give up. My goal is to finish this album by early 2019.

So there you have it. I’m starting on an album adventure and I want you to join me. Thank you for listening and for your support.

LINKS TO HEAR MY PREVIOUS WORK:

SOLO:

Spotify Link: https://open.spotify.com/artist/0z9ihAaol8L9Z4H...

"Homewrecker's Lament" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkWx-qODAak

"The Lie" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eAXlzjv3OVM

"Motel Daughters" feat. John Stirratt of Wilco https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5BO128A0O9M

"Eggshells and Landmines" feat. Grazyna Auguscik https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNUMk96ACEw


With SOFTWARE GIANT (Lead Vocals, Lyrics)

Spotify Link: https://open.spotify.com/artist/0iYHC2YY7WZ6KEp...

"Maldives" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/maldives

"The Current" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/the-cu...

"Flesh and Folly" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/flesh-...

And I’m excited to say that I’ll be working with the fabulous Adam Muñoz at the legendary Fantasy Studios in Berkeley, CA.Fantasy Studios is known around the world and has recorded some really important musicians: Santana, Tony Bennett, Aerosmith, En Vogue, Journey! And Adam Muñoz has recorded some of my favorite singers including Chris Isaak, Bonnie Raitt, Mike Patton, and Paula Cole.I can’t wait for you to hear these songs. They’re the tightest and most lyrically honest of my work to date. I’ve started recording and the video above has some sneak peeks of me in the studio.With your support, I can also bring in other pro musicians to help flesh out these songs and really raise them up. These songs are so close to being fully realized – with your help we can give them a life of their own.Here's a Break-Down of Estimated Recording Costs for 9 SongsTracking Drums and Bass (20 hours) = $2200Electric Guitar Overdubs (16 hours) = $1760Acoustic Instrument Overdubs: Acoustic Guitar, Piano, Mandolin (16 hours) = $1760Lead Vocal Overdubs (24 hours) = $2640Back Up Vocal Overdubs (16 hours) = $1760Mixing (40 hours) = $4400Mastering = $600Total: $15,120“So why should you fund it?”  Well, you’ll get a well-crafted, lyrically honest Rock Americana record and the good will knowing that you helped make it with me, an independent artist. Plus, I have some perks to help sweeten the deal. That includes a private house concert. Or making Pasta All’amatriciana for you.If you’re saying, “How do I know Dylan is going to actually finish the album?” Well, I have a great track record of releasing 3 albums (See Links Below). Just ask my friends. I’m driven and I don’t give up. Seriously, I don’t give up. My goal is to finish this album by early 2019.So there you have it. I’m starting on an album adventure and I want you to join me. Thank you for listening and for your support.LINKS TO HEAR MY PREVIOUS WORK:SOLO:Spotify Link: https://open.spotify.com/artist/0z9ihAaol8L9Z4H..."Homewrecker's Lament" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkWx-qODAak"The Lie" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eAXlzjv3OVM"Motel Daughters" feat. John Stirratt of Wilco https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5BO128A0O9M"Eggshells and Landmines" feat. Grazyna Auguscik https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNUMk96ACEwWith SOFTWARE GIANT (Lead Vocals, Lyrics)Spotify Link: https://open.spotify.com/artist/0iYHC2YY7WZ6KEp..."Maldives" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/maldives"The Current" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/the-cu..."Flesh and Folly" https://softwaregiant.bandcamp.com/track/flesh-...

story:
It's been a hectic time at In Search Of Symmetry HQ with a change to our plans for our August recording schedule at STL Studios, NSW, Australia. We will still be teaming up with Sonny Truelove, except on the other side of the world, with the folks at Castle Recording Studios in Nashville, TN, USA.

And we want our fans to get in on the action!

The decision to record in Nashville came about as a result of an opportunity with Sonny Truelove; the Producer and Mix Engineer of our first two releases. Traveling to the musical capitol of the world, was a complete no brainer, and "an offer we couldn't refuse" 

Sonny has hooked up with the legendary team at The Castle,  who've recorded artists such as Bob Dylan, Johnny Cash, Bruce Springsteen, Snoop Dogg, Bon Jovi, Megadeth & Mayday Parade.

We want our most diehard fans to experience this epic musical journey through a limited series of crowd-funded special release packages.  Get your hands on some really great merch, special experiences and the new album when it is released!

We cant wait to share this once in a lifetime experience with you.

<3 ISOS

https://www.facebook.com/insearchofsymmetryrock/

https://www.youtube.com/user/insearchofsymmetry

www.soundcloud.com/insearchofsymmetry

www.instagram.com/insearchofsymmetry

https://insearchofsymmetry.bandcamp.com

story:
The Project

Cape Town Swing is a volunteer-run, non-profit organization lead by a group of local dancers dedicated to organising swing dance events in the area. Echoes of Sophiatown extends from our aim to build community through a shared interested in dance and to foster an appreciation for swing dance, music, and history.

The story of swing dance and music in South Africa is a rich one that parallels the story of swing in America, in both its origins within black communities and its expression of systemic injustice. And yet, few in the international dance community (and even the greater South African community) are familiar with its heroes and the remarkable music they made.

The social and political oppression of black South Africans under the apartheid regime left much of the South African swing era from the 1930s through the 1950s undocumented. Few music recordings, photographs, video footage, or historical records of any kind are publicly available, if they exist at all. Those artifacts that do exist are largely gathering dust in private collections and archives, waiting to be rediscovered.

Sophiatown was a hub of black culture similar in some ways to Harlem in New York. Swing music flourished in this multi-cultural suburb until the apartheid government bulldozed the entire neighbourhood and replaced it with a whites-only area. Much of the culture was lost and the bands were dispersed but a few recordings remain.

Our team has identified a list of songs by various local artists and in different states of integrity. This  project will begin the process of preserving and reviving this music by transcribing, recording, and performing 30 original South African swing songs, which will be made available to a new generation of music and dance appreciators.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $12,000 for the Echoes of Sophiatown project to serve three objectives:

1) Music
We aim to transcribe 30 songs that can be performed and recorded for a wider audience. Our local swing band, The Pebble Shakers, will debut the compilation at our annual dance festival, Mother City Hop (www.mothercityhop.com), in March 2019.

We will be releasing the list of songs in 3 batches of 10.
The first 10 songs are listed below and can be heard at www.pebbleshakers.co.za/#echoes:

Swazi Stomp - African Swingsters - SPONSORED by Simon
Third Avenue Special - Alexandra All Star Band - SPONSORED by Christine
Skokiaan - The Bulawayo Sweet Rhythm Band
Lo Tsosi - Damuza Mdledle
Unomeva - Dolly Rathebe
Diepkloof Ekhaya - Jazz Dazzlers - SPONSORED
Dipsy Doodle - Manhattan Brothers
Sweet Talk - Manhattan Brothers - SPONSORED
Kalla’s Special - Spokes Mashiyane - SPONSORED
Boogie Woogie Wam - Walter Theletsane

2) History
Our team will research, compile, and document the stories of the artists and the events around the creation of the songs we are transcribing.

3) Art 
To accompany the music and pay tribute to the musicians, we will be curating a collection of artwork and photography that is either from the time period or inspired by the era. An exhibition of the collection will be held in March 2019.

Perk Highlights

Echoes of Sophiatown on Vinyl -  a limited edition record featuring a selection of the songs we transcribe, performed by the Pebble Shakers (50 available at $40)

Art Prints: a limited edition print of one of the three featured artworks from the Echoes of Sophiatown exhibition (10 available of each artwork at $100).

Sponsor a song: for $350 you can help cover the costs for one of the transcriptions and have you name appear on the record cover, e.g.:
"Meadowlands Boogie," sponsored by Frankie Manning.

Sneak Peak Event: an intimate listening session with the Pebble Shakers before their big show in March 2019 (25 available at $12)

Our target reflects the cost of a minimalist approach to transcribing and recording the minimum number of songs required to have an all-South African swing set list.  If we are unable to reach our target we will need to go back to the drawing board. We are not willing to do this project in a way that would compromise the quality or pay less than full respect to the musicians from the era or those involved in the transcription.

The Impact

Echoes of Sophiatown serves two communities, different in scale, but with overlapping interests.

The international swing dance community takes pride in the preservation and celebration of history and culture of the music and dance we love. We do this implicitly every time we take to the dance floor, and great effort has been taken to document, share, and honor the tapestry of stories, music, and people that define our culture. Currently missing from this tapestry is the story of South African swing, which is suffused with exciting rhythms, personalities, and a culture all its own. The revival of South African swing promises to enrich our dancing and our understanding of the music that makes it possible.

More importantly however is the greater South African community, and in particular, the people who's culture the apartheid government tried to destroy. Nearly 25 years since the democratisation of the country, South Africans are still exploring our national and cultural identity, comprised as it is of so many languages, traditions, and  histories. Vital to the process of figuring out where we are headed as a society is understanding where we came from. The South African swing era represents one cultural moment, a single piece in the bigger puzzle of our national heritage, that can be a source of pride, learning, joy, and, as it was originally, a way to bring people together. In this regard, we want Echoes of Sophiatown to shine a light on the unsung heros of our musical past and to be a source of joy and connection in our fractured society.

Risks & Challenges

Our first priority in this project is to honor the original South African artists who, consequent to their political marginalisation, were not just under-recognised but under-compensated for their work. We face real challenges in determining the copyright status of the music we want to preserve, as well as in ensuring that we pay the artists at the heart of this project (and their families) proper respect both in spirit and in monetary terms.

We understand that our goal to perform and record song covers raises concerns about a) profitability and b) cultural appropriation. We want to be clear that we are not interested in turning a profit on this music for our organisation, or any of us individually. Our aim is to make this music available to the public in a sustainable way, while covering the costs of production. We are also interested in finding ways for the original artists to receive monetary rewards for the fruits of their original music. We are currently engaging with the legalities and practicalities of this challenge and will continue to post updates on our progress in this regard.

Although we represent a largely white community, this is an unfortunate reflection of our segregated city and something we are actively trying to change. We have been, and will continue to be, consulting with the communities where this music originated and the few musicians from the era that are still alive. So far, the response has been largely one of joy and support. 

A portion of the funds we raise will be used in tracking down the original artists and their families.  The legal tangle around music rights and royalties is not trivial but we hope to find a means to channel any additional income we raise towards these communities in a sustainable manner.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help us beyond contributing to our campaign:

  • Spread the word about the campaign to friends who share our mission using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Promote South African swing music by listening and dancing to the music in your own community.
  • Join us at the Mother City Hop festival in March 2019 to hear this music live.

Note: A big thank you to Jurgen Schadeberg (https://www.jurgenschadeberg.com/) who allowed us to use his wonderful photographs from Sophiatown.

story:
From Tuxedos to Kilts

My life in music started on the stage of the Bass Hall with the Ft. Worth Opera.  I was a classical singer for 13 years in the US and abroad, but in my heart I always served two masters. 

Growing up listening my grandfather and his friends play traditional bluegrass, it wasn't a far leap from there to find the traditional music of Ireland, and there, I found a home.  Upon leaving the opera, I continued to play traditional music in local area pubs and renaissance festivals around Northeast Texas until I moved to upstate New York.  Since transitioning to the Northeast, I have discovered a vibrant culture of traditional music, not only Irish, but American, and Canadian as well.  Having the pleasure of knowing and playing with numerous outstanding musicians makes this collaboration all the more rich.  It has been an amazing musical adventure, and this album is a map of my journey.  

Every journey needs some gas money

The goal is to continue to keep my projects like this as lean as possible, without sacrificing quality.  To that end I'm asking for $2,000 to get this album off the ground.  Your support will help to fund the following:

  • Recording and mixing time with Blue Sky studios (the engineer is also an Irish musician, so mixing the style is second nature).

  • Album mastering.

  • Paying the other musicians for their time and travel expenses.

  • Compensating the fantastic graphic designer (who has worked with me on a previous classical album) for the album artwork and layout. 

  • Initial print run of CDs.

 

Tread the road together

Creating this work has been on my mind for several years now. I challenged myself to put together an album that will evoke the full range of emotions captured in the stories these songs tell.  Re-energizing the arrangements with the help of fellow musicians and singers, this collection will be a labor of love.

Your support will help to make this a success, and your contribution comes with its own perks as well:

  • A heartfelt “Thank You”

  • Early access to the digital album

  • Signed copies of the CD, once released

  • Recognition in the album liner 

  • Personalized video "Thank You",  including song requests

  • House concerts for you and your guests

 

Your “Voice” is just as helpful

I know that not everyone can contribute monetarily to this project.  However, if you can take some time to share this campaign with your friends and family, spreading the word for me, I would be truly thankful.  Cheers!

story:
Hey, Side Project fans/friends!

We are so passionate about releasing our first Christmas CD called "Holiday" and we could use the help of our fans and friends to get it done!  If you would like to enjoy one of the unique perks we have created, then please donate to our campaign!  We will be forever grateful and do our best to make it worth your while.

  • As you probably know we have been wanting to release a Christmas album for a few years and we finally have the chance to do it now.
  • We are recording LIVE (the full band at the same time) in the studio, and although it is much more challenging, the sound and feel of these recordings is very transparent like a live performance.  Many of you have requested a more "live sounding" recording like this and your generosity will enable us to achieve this.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need funding for the CD to be recorded, mixed, mastered, art work designed, and duplicated.
  • Our special and unique perks were created for you.  We hope you find one that you like.  We are excited to give back to you!

The Impact

  • We have had a successful track record with projects like this (such as our last album called "Cover Up").  We truly would not be where we are at today if it weren't for you and your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, it doesn't mean you can't help:

  • We are asking all our peeps to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • You can also spread the word by using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
For the past two years, we at The Djukella Orchestra have been crafting a fine new album for your listening pleasure. Now it's very nearly ready and we just need to pay for it. In between racing around the UK and chunks of Europe playing our hearts out, we've taken every chance we got to record a set of powerful songs and stonking tunes including old favourites from our live repertoire and some brand new gems. 

Featuring the combined fiddling prowess of Messrs James Patrick Gavin and Alastair Caplin, the mellifluous groove of "Master of Space and Time" Nye Parsons on the double-bass, Dominic Henderson on Uillean pipes, Tommie Black-Roff on accordion and cameos from Ewan Bleach on clarinet and James "Proffessor Bongo" Hegarty on the mysterious pandero, it's a smorgasbord of musical styles and lyrical magic, and comes replete with fine photography, original artwork and a twenty page booklet.

Recorded by Sam Welbourne on some of the finest microphones Neumann can provide, I've been told by several people that it sounds like the band are right there in the room with you.

How You Can Help...
To help us pay for the manufacture of the album, you can order your copy in advance and we'll send it to you in the post as soon as we receive them from the factory. 

If you're feeling rich, generous or just easily led, you can donate a little more than the cost of the album or choose other perks from the list on the right here.

We've poured heart and soul into this record and are really proud of the finished product. I have a feeling that you're going to love it, too. Anyone who has enjoyed our first album "Blood & Honey" or this year's "Live on the Ley" will definitely get a kick out of "Heavy Wood". In my humble opinion, it's the best thing I've ever recorded.

In between racing around the UK and chunks of Europe playing our hearts out, we've taken every chance we got to record a set of powerful songs and stonking tunes including old favourites from our live repertoire and some brand new gems. 
Featuring the combined fiddling prowess of Messrs James Patrick Gavin and Alastair Caplin, the mellifluous groove of "Master of Space and Time" Nye Parsons on the double-bass, Dominic Henderson on Uillean pipes, Tommie Black-Roff on accordion and cameos from Ewan Bleach on clarinet and James "Proffessor Bongo" Hegarty on the mysterious pandero, it's a smorgasbord of musical styles and lyrical magic, and comes replete with fine photography, original artwork and a twenty page booklet.Recorded by Sam Welbourne on some of the finest microphones Neumann can provide, I've been told by several people that it sounds like the band are right there in the room with you.How You Can Help...To help us pay for the manufacture of the album, you can order your copy in advance and we'll send it to you in the post as soon as we receive them from the factory. If you're feeling rich, generous or just easily led, you can donate a little more than the cost of the album or choose other perks from the list on the right here.We've poured heart and soul into this record and are really proud of the finished product. I have a feeling that you're going to love it, too. Anyone who has enjoyed our first album "Blood & Honey" or this year's "Live on the Ley" will definitely get a kick out of "Heavy Wood". In my humble opinion, it's the best thing I've ever recorded.
